D. S. and R.Z. contributed equally to this paper. Achieving precise control over stereochemistry in polymerization processes remains an essential goal of modern polymer science, as it directly impacts material properties such as crystallinity, degradability, and mechanical strength. Organocatalysis has emerged as a powerful strategy, offering metal-free conditions, structural tunability, and broad monomer compatibility. However, the origin of stereocontrol in these systems often hinges on subtle noncovalent interactions and conformational effects that are challenging to elucidate experimentally. In this perspective, we highlight how density functional theory (DFT) has provided critical insights into the mechanisms governing enantio‑ and diastereoselectivity in organocatalyzed polymerizations. We discuss representative case studies involving ring-opening polymerization (ROP) and conjugate-addition polymerizations, emphasizing how computational models have clarified the role of hydrogen bonding, steric hindrance, catalyst chirality, and monomer orientation in dictating tacticity. Furthermore, we examine how DFT complements experimental data in the rational design of new catalysts and explore the limitations and emerging frontiers in computational polymer catalysis. By bridging theory and practice, DFT-based studies are poised to accelerate the development of next-generation stereoselective organocatalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Stereoselective polymerization DFT calculations Organocatalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The development of polymeric materials has evolved from empirical experimentation to a more rational, design-driven approach. While early advances relied heavily on trial and error, precise control over key parameters, such as kinetics, stereoregularity, dispersity, sequence distribution, functionality, and macromolecular architecture, is now essential for tailoring material properties [1–3]. Achieving this control requires a solid mechanistic foundation and a deep theoretical understanding of polymerization processes. The scientific community's attention has therefore gradually focused on strategies capable of accurately modulating these aspects to obtain materials with specific and predictable properties. In particular, stereochemical control during the polymerization process is of primary importance: a stereoregular configuration is often essential for the formation of crystalline polymers, which typically display markedly enhanced mechanical, thermal, and optical properties compared to their amorphous analogues [4–7]. Consequently, achieving precise control over stereoregularity has become a central goal in the synthesis of functional and high-performance polymers. The discovery and development of new polymeric materials has evolved significantly, from the early reliance on heterogeneous catalytic systems to the emergence of highly defined homogeneous catalysts, and more recently, to the expanding field of organocatalysis. A key turning point occurred in 1954, when Giulio Natta successfully synthesized the first stereoregular polymer, isotactic polypropylene, using a heterogeneous organometallic catalyst [4]. This milestone initiated a new era in polymer chemistry, marked by an intense focus on stereocontrolled polymerizations. While such catalysts remain vital in industry for their robustness and efficiency, their inherently heterogeneous nature featuring multiple structurally distinct active sites, limits precise control over polymerization parameters, especially stereoselectivity [8]. To address this, research has shifted toward transition metal (TM) based homogeneous catalysts with well-defined structures (LnMR), enabling fine control over polymer properties such as molecular weight, sequence, and stereochemistry. Although their application in solution-phase industrial processes may be limited due to their low thermal stability, a key advantage is that their well-defined structure offers unique opportunities for detailed mechanistic and structural studies, which are essential for the development of new-generation catalysts. Theoretical and experimental investigations of these systems have helped to decode the mechanisms by which stereoregular polymers are obtained. From a mechanistic perspective, stereoselective polymerization generally proceeds via two main pathways: chain-end control (CEC) and enantiomorphic site control (ESC) [9,10]. In the first case, the chirality of the propagating chain end influences the stereochemistry of monomer insertion. In the second case, the chiral environment of the catalyst governs the stereochemical outcome independently of the chain end. Depending on the nature of the catalyst, polymerization may proceed through ESC, CEC, or a combination of both mechanisms. Due to the wide range of metal-ligand combinations, TM-based catalysts have historically dominated stereoselective polymerization processes [11–14]. However, the growing demand for sustainable alternatives to traditional polyolefins has brought increasing attention to polymeric materials derived from biorenewable resources. In this context, ring-opening polymerization (ROP) has emerged as a powerful strategy for the polymerization of cyclic (di)esters, with stereoselective ROP standing out due to the crucial role that stereochemical control plays in determining the physical properties of the resulting materials [15]. This has been considered a very challenging game for chemists [16] because the very high level of understanding achieved with TM-olefin catalyzed has to date not been reached in ROP catalysis. Finally, growing concerns about cost, toxicity, and sustainability have fuelled increasing interest in metal-free alternatives. Since Hedrick's pioneering work in 2001, the use of organocatalysts in ROP of lactides and other cyclic esters has made remarkable progress, to the point of offering viable and, in some cases, superior alternatives to traditional metal-based systems [17,18]. Organocatalysts are generally inexpensive, commercially available, and stable to air and moisture, which makes them easy to handle and store. Furthermore, their lower toxicity makes them inherently safer for both humans and the environment. They also show broad functional group tolerance, particularly in the presence of heteroatoms such as sulphur, phosphorus, or nitrogen, which are known to deactivate many metal complexes [19]. Moreover, due to their acid/base nature, organocatalysts can often be easily removed from the final polymer by simple washing or immobilization on solid supports. Mechanistically, organocatalysts operate through a variety of activation modes depending on their chemical structure: (i) basic activation of the initiator or chain end, (ii) nucleophilic or electrophilic activation of the monomer, and (iii) bifunctional activation, which involves simultaneous interaction with both the monomer and the initiator or chain end during propagation [18]. This mechanistic diversity broadens the possibilities for controlling reaction rate and selectivity, facilitating the synthesis of complex polymer architectures that are difficult to access using traditional coordination-insertion mechanisms. However, for the same reason, achieving stereoselective polymerization via organocatalysis remains a non-trivial challenge. In fact, unlike metal-based systems, where stereocontrol is often driven by well-known insertion mechanisms, organocatalysts often follow less predictable activation pathways. As a result, successful examples of stereoselective polymerization using organocatalysts remain relatively few and in only a handful of cases have the stereocontrol mechanisms been thoroughly elucidated. This limited understanding represents a significant obstacle to the rational design of new organocatalysts for stereocontrolled polymerizations. From this perspective, we underscore the pivotal role of Density Functional Theory (DFT) in unravelling the mechanisms underlying stereocontrol in organocatalyzed polymerizations. Over the past few decades, DFT has emerged as an indispensable tool for interpreting complex stereochemical outcomes, offering molecular-level insights that often go beyond the reach of experimental techniques. By enabling the detailed analysis of reaction energetics, conformational landscapes, and key noncovalent interactions, DFT provides critical understanding of the factors governing enantio‑ and diastereoselectivity. These insights are instrumental in guiding the rational design of next generation organocatalysts for stereoselective polymerizations. In this context, we examine selected case studies where DFT has been successfully applied to clarify the origins of stereoselectivity. Our goal is to illustrate how theoretical models can complement experimental findings and guide catalyst design in this complex and rapidly evolving area of polymer chemistry. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 ROP of lactide Polylactide (PLA), a biodegradable aliphatic polyester, is one of the most promising candidates to rival commercial polyolefins in terms of mechanical and thermal performance [20]. As lactide (LA) possesses two chiral centres, the ROP of its three stereoisomers (L-LA, d -LA, and meso‑LA), as well as the racemic mixture (rac-LA), can produce a range of PLA microstructures with different physicochemical properties (Scheme 1 ). Computational studies [21–22] have demonstrated that the ROP mechanism of LA promoted by mono-component and bifunctional catalysts proceeds via a pathway such as the one illustrated in Scheme 2 . This mechanism involves at least two key transition states: TS1, corresponding to the nucleophilic attack of the initiator/growing chain-end on the lactide carbonyl; and TS2, representing the subsequent ring-opening step following the intermediate 1 (INT1) and leading to the INT2. The identification of the rate determining step (RDS) is not an easy task although it is fundamental for a detailed knowledge of the mechanistic path. While numerous organocatalysts have demonstrated high polymerization rates, only a limited number of studies have investigated the stereocontrolled ROP of LA, particularly from a computational perspective which, as mentioned above, remains essential for elucidating the underlying mechanisms and guiding catalyst design. In the following, we provide a comprehensive overview of published studies that have applied DFT to investigate the stereocontrolled ROP of LA. 2.1.1 Proline derivatives One of the earliest studies on organocatalyzed stereoselective ROP is the seminal work by Cossío and Mecerreyes, who employed a chiral l -proline-derived catalyst to polymerize rac-LA, achieving high isotacticity [23]. Both computational (M06–2X(PCM)/6–31+G(d,p)//B3LYP/6–31G(d)) and experimental studies have confirmed the effectiveness of this approach, demonstrating that the chirality of the organocatalyst is successfully transferred to the growing polymer chain, resulting in the formation of highly stereoregular poly(lactide). This system stands out as one of the few documented examples of organocatalysts operating through an ESC mechanism, where the catalyst’s three-dimensional chiral environment dictates the stereochemistry of monomer insertion, independent of the configuration of the propagating polymer chain. The organocatalyst was synthesized as two diastereomeric forms, both derived from amino acids and featuring dense substitutions (Fig. 1 ). To promote the reaction, the organocatalyst was used in combination with DBU (1,8-diazabicyclo[5.4.0]undec‑7-ene) as a co-catalyst, and benzyl alcohol (BnOH) as the initiator. Both diastereomers exhibited exceptional catalytic performance, facilitating the synthesis of isotactic poly(lactide) with a high degree of isotacticity (Pₘ > 0.90). Remarkably, they also showed clear enantioselectivity: exo-6 preferentially polymerized l -LA, while endo-6 favoured d -LA and DFT calculations were performed to elucidate the underlying ESC mechanism. As noted by the authors, the simultaneous interactions between the catalyst (endo or exo), the monomer, and methanol (used as a model instead of BnOH initiator) capture the key factors driving stereochemical control (highlighted in the grey box in Fig. 2 ). In this scenario, the lactide’s interaction with the catalyst's carboxyl group activates the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO), increasing its electrophilicity. At the same time, the alcohol’s hydroxyl group is activated via interaction with the tertiary amine group of the organocatalyst, raising its highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) energy. This dual activation of both the monomer and initiator not only facilitates their spatial proximity and lowers the activation barrier but also plays a decisive role in determining the stereochemical outcome of the polymerization. A conformational analysis of the pyrrolidine ring revealed that the most stable conformations place the carboxyl group and phenyl substituents in equatorial positions, while the N-methyl group can adopt either axial or equatorial positions relative to the carboxyl group, leading to two distinct conformers, termed syn and anti (Fig. 2b). Building on these observations, the authors paired the organocatalyst conformations with the specific coordination modes of the monomer and initiator to explore the origin of stereocontrol. For l-lactide, the lowest-energy TS occurs when the exo-6 organocatalyst adopts the anti-conformation, with a 2 kcal/mol energy advantage over the syn conformation. Likewise, for d -lactide, the anti-conformation is also favoured, exhibiting a more pronounced energy difference of 9 kcal/mol. The comparison of the two most stable TSs (Fig. 2c) reveals a 0.9 kcal/mol preference the l -lactide complex. While modest, this gap aligns with the observed stereochemical control and suggests that exo-6 selectively promotes l -lactide polymerization. Notably, the calculated selectivity ratio of 83:17 (S,S):(R,R) closely matches the experimental value of 86:14, confirming the accuracy of the predictions. The same analysis carried out for endo-6 catalyst showed that the lowest-energy TS occurs in the syn conformation (Fig. 2c), while the corresponding anti TS for l -lactide is disfavoured by approximately 0.3 kcal/mol. Again, despite the small energy difference, this shift explains the catalyst's preference for d -lactide, with a theoretical enantioselectivity ratio of 38:62 (S,S):(R,R), in close agreement with the experimental ratio of 30:70. This study highlights the power of computational modelling in rationalizing stereochemical outcomes in organocatalyzed ROP, providing valuable insights to guide catalyst design and optimization. DFT calculations successfully revealed the key non-covalent interactions between the catalyst and the enantiomerically defined monomer that drive stereoselectivity. The results emphasize that a detailed analysis of catalyst conformations is crucial for understanding selectivity, underscoring the importance of structural insights in the development of more efficient catalytic systems. This pioneering example illustrates stereocontrol governed by an ESC mechanism, while the following sections highlight how alternative activation modes can further expand the strategies available for achieving stereocontrol. 2.1.2 DMAP: MSA The work of Sardon’s team marked a key advancement in developing thermally stable, metal-free catalysts for the ROP of l -lactide [24]. Their system, based on a 4-(Dimethylamino) pyrimidine: Methanesulfonic acid complex (DMAP: MSA) in a 1:2 ratio, enabled efficient bulk polymerization at 130 °C using benzyl alcohol as initiator. The process yielded high-molecular-weight, stereoregular PLLA with no evidence of epimerization or transesterification (Scheme 3 ). The catalytic activity of the system stems from the formation of thermally stable ionic salts with a supramolecular structure that governs both reactivity and selectivity. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA), confirmed the high thermal stability of the 1:2 complex, which showed decomposition only above 250 °C. DFT calculations (ωB97XD/6–311++G(2df,2p)//ωB97XD/6–31+G(d,p)) revealed that the dissociation energy increases markedly from 19.4 kcal/mol (1:1 complex) to 41.3 kcal/mol (1:2 complex), an effect attributed to an additional proton transfer between MSA molecules in the 1:2 system. NMR (¹H and ¹⁵N) analyses corroborated the formation of ionic species and selective protonation at the aromatic nitrogen of DMAP, in line with computational findings. Catalytic testing showed that the stoichiometric DMAP: MSA complex (1:1) exhibited the highest catalytic activity, reaching 99 % conversion within just 2 h. In contrast, the acidic 1:2 complex required 15 h to achieve a comparable conversion (97 %). This difference was attributed to stronger electrostatic activation of the monomer’s carbonyl group in the 1:1 system, as evidenced by downfield shifts in the ¹³C NMR spectra. We also believe that the difference in velocity arises from the lower reactivity of the propagating species, which, in the 1:2 system, is predominantly protonated due to the more proton-rich environment—unlike in the 1:1 condition. However, analysis of the resulting polymer microstructure revealed that the 1:2 complex provided markedly improved stereocontrol. The stereoregularity parameter (Pₘ) reached 0.98 with the acidic catalyst, compared to only 0.52 for the stoichiometric one, clearly indicating that the 1:2 ratio effectively suppresses side reactions such as epimerization and transesterification. To further understand the origin of this behaviour, DFT calculations were performed to investigate the initiation and epimerization steps of the ROP mechanism (Scheme 4 ). The results showed that although the TSs for the initiation step (TS I1) have comparable activation barriers, 23.6 kcal/mol for DMAP: MSA (1:1) and 21.5 kcal/mol for DMAP: MSA (1:2), the overall energy landscapes differed significantly. In the stoichiometric system (1:1), all TSs and INTs lie below the reference energy level (ΔG < 0), indicating a kinetically and thermodynamically favourable process. By contrast, the 1:2 system displays a less favourable energy profile. While the initial complex is modestly stabilized (–9.6 kcal/mol), subsequent TSs and INTs rise above the reference energy, with activation barriers of 11.9 and 13.4 kcal/mol and a final intermediate at 5.6 kcal/mol. This reduced thermodynamic driving force explains the experimentally observed slower kinetics, approximately sevenfold lower than that of the 1:1 system. A key insight from this study is the role of epimerization in undermining stereochemical control. The isomerization of l -LA to meso‑LA was found to be energetically accessible with DMAP: MSA (1:1) system, requiring only 11.3 kcal/mol (Fig. 3 ), comparable to the initiation barrier (11.9 kcal/mol). This low barrier explains the 18 % epimerization observed experimentally. In contrast, the same process catalysed by DMAP: MSA (1:2) has a much higher barrier (28.2 kcal/mol), well above the thermally accessible range, making epimerization highly unlikely. This finding explains the markedly improved stereocontrol observed with the 1:2 system, which, despite its lower reactivity, effectively suppresses undesired configurational isomerization. Although the paper does not state this explicitly, the difference in epimerization barriers between the two systems may stem from more effective activation of the monomer carbonyl in the 1:1 mixture compared to the 1:2 mixture. In the 1:1 system, stronger carbonyl activation increases the acidity of the α-proton, facilitating its abstraction. This interpretation is supported by the observation that adding an extra equivalent of MSA (forming a 1:2 mixture) leads to the formation of a stable DMAPH⁺–MSA ion-paired complex. This complex appears to activate the carbonyl less efficiently than DMAPH⁺ alone, thereby diminishing both nucleophilic addition and α-deprotonation. In summary, the two catalytic systems reveal a clear trade-off between kinetic efficiency and stereochemical control: while the stoichiometric mixture ensures fast polymerization due to its favourable energy profile, the acidic system enhances stereocontrol by inhibiting epimerization, making it the preferred choice when high stereoregularity is required. This system emphasizes the role of supramolecular ionic interactions in dictating stereocontrol; we next consider the base catalyst TBD, where stereocontrol is imposed during propagation. 2.1.3 TBD Although Triazabicyclodecene (TBD)-catalysed ring-opening polymerization of rac-lactide has been widely investigated at room temperature (P m = 0.58), its stereoselectivity remained unexplored until recently. Dove and co-workers were the first to report the TBD-catalysed ROP of rac-LA under cryogenic conditions [25]. Starting from rac-LA at −75 °C in toluene or dichloromethane, the process led to the formation of isotactic PLA (P m up to 0.88), with low dispersity, and a melting point consistent with a semicrystalline microstructure. Further experiments using meso‑LA produced heterotactic PLA (P m = 0.80), underscoring the influence of the propagating alcohol on stereoselectivity through a CEC mechanism. These results suggested that stereocontrol arises from synergistic interactions among the monomer, the propagating chain end, and the catalyst. This hypothesis aligns with prior mechanistic studies by Rice et al. [26], who computationally identified two possible distinct pathways for TBD-catalysed ROP of l-LA: (i) a dual lactide activation/nucleophilic mechanism, in which the catalyst mediates ring-opening and proton transfer and (ii) a hydrogen-bonding mechanism based on simultaneous activation of both the lactide and the nucleophilic alcohol (Fig. 4 ) [27]. In both mechanisms, the RDS is the nucleophilic addition of the alcohol. However, the first pathway, where ring opening precedes alcohol addition, was found to be energetically unfavourable; the key RDS of the second pathway is illustrated in Fig. 5 [27]. Building on this evidence and aiming to clarify the origin of the experimentally observed stereoselectivity, Dove's group conducted a DFT (ωB97XD/6–31G**) study focused on the rate-determining alcohol addition step. To model the interaction between the propagating chain end and the monomer, methyl-(L)-lactate was used as a representative alcohol, while meso‑lactide was selected as the monomer due to its symmetry, which enables discrimination between nucleophilic attack at the carbonyl near to the R or S stereocenters. DFT calculations identified two competing TSs (I and II), corresponding to nucleophilic attack of the alcohol on the (S)- or (R)-center of the lactide, respectively (Fig. 6 ). In both cases, the TS involves a dual activation by TBD: concerted proton transfer from the alcohol to the guanidino group and hydrogen-bond to the lactone carbonyl. TS-I, corresponding to nucleophilic attack at the (S) centre of the lactide, was calculated to be 2.6 kcal/mol lower in energy than TS-II and this energy difference was attributed to a more favourable Bürgi–Dunitz alignment, as reflected by a shorter O···C distance between the alcohol and carbonyl (2.62 Å vs. 2.79 Å), resulting in reduced distortion along the reaction coordinate. These findings suggest that an (S)-configured alcohol favours the formation of a terminal (R) unit, while an (R) alcohol yields the (S) unit, consistent with the experimentally observed heterotacticity in meso‑lactide polymerization. Based on both computational and experimental evidence, the observed stereocontrol arises from a CEC mechanism, where the chirality of the growing chain influences monomer insertion. In this model, spatial interactions between the stereogenic chain end and the incoming monomer, combined with the conformational constraints imposed by TBD’s dual bifunctional activation, drive the selective insertion of one lactide enantiomer over the other. DFT calculations thus offer a clear rationale for the high isoselectivity observed in the TBD-catalysed ROP of rac-lactide, highlighting the crucial role of chiral discrimination between TSs enabled by the catalyst’s cooperative and conformationally restricted activation. 2.1.4 Thiourea derivatives Whereas the TBD-based systems discussed in the previous section rely exclusively on a CEC mechanism for stereocontrol, other systems were found to combine both ESC and CEC contributions, as discussed below. To this extent, thiourea-based organocatalysts, such as those shown in Fig. 7 , have been among the most extensively studied systems for the stereoselective ROP of rac-LA [28–34]. Within this class, catalysts 5–8 demonstrated excellent control over molecular weight (Mn = 16,700–21,100 g mol⁻¹) and narrow dispersity (Đ < 1.10) but exhibited only moderate stereoselectivity at room temperature. In contrast, catalysts 1–3 achieved significantly higher levels of isoselectivity. Nevertheless, although significant research effort has been dedicated to these systems, DFT-based mechanistic studies aimed at uncovering the origins of their stereocontrol have only recently emerged. In a recent study, Taton and co-workers evaluated both enantiomeric forms of Takemoto’s catalyst (Fig. 7, catalyst 1) in the ROP of rac-LA, using benzyl alcohol (BnOH) as the initiator and conducting the reactions in either dichloromethane or toluene over a temperature range of 25–85 °C [32]. Notably, each enantiomer of the catalyst exhibited enantiodiscrimination toward the monomers: (S,S)-1 preferentially incorporated d -LA (R,R-LA), while (R,R)-1 favoured the insertion of l -LA (S,S-LA). Kinetic studies, together with detailed analyses of the resulting PLAs, indicated that the underlying stereocontrol arises from the combined action of ESC and CEC mechanisms. This dual contribution is reflected in the high degrees of isotacticity observed: PLA derived from (S,S)-Takemoto exhibited a P m value of 0.87, while the (R,R)-Takemoto reached an even higher P m of 0.90 when the polymerization was carried out in toluene at room temperature.To gain deeper insight into the origin of stereocontrol exerted by Takemoto’s catalyst, a detailed DFT investigation (B3LYP-D3(cPCM)/TZVP//B3LYP-D3/6–31G(d)) was carried out, focusing on the ROP of rac-LA catalysed by the (R,R)-1 catalyst [35]. The analysis of the initiation step revealed that d -LA and l -LA follow distinct pathways, each favouring a different enantioface: re for d -LA and si for l -LA (Fig. 8 ). This enantioface discrimination was found to directly impact the energy profile, with l -LA insertion being preferred (ΔΔG ‡ of 1.9 kcal/mol), consistent with experimental observations and indicative of an ESC mechanism. Interestingly, also the RDS differed between the two enantiomers: for l -LA, the nucleophilic attack (TS1) was identified as rate-limiting, whereas for d -LA, the ring-opening step (TS2) constituted the RDS (Fig. 9 ). This model was extended to the propagation step, where the stereochemistry of the chain end was shown to influence monomer insertion preference, thus confirming the additional contribution of a CEC mechanism; the corresponding rate-determining transition states are reported in Fig. 10 . The cooperative action of ESC and CEC mechanisms resulted in a clear energetic discrimination, in good agreement with the experimental results (P m = 0.90). These mechanistic insights were further supported by Activation Strain Model (ASM) and Noncovalent Interaction (NCI) analyses [36–38]. ASM revealed that activation barriers are mainly governed by monomer deformation rather than catalyst–monomer interaction. The (R,R)-1 catalyst favours l -LA insertion due to less strained transition states. NCI analysis confirmed stabilizing CH-π and CH-F noncovalent interactions in the l -LA (si) TS (Fig. 10A), particularly between the growing polymer chain and the catalyst’s aryl ring, interactions absent in the d -LA (re) TS (Fig. 10B), thereby contributing to a higher activation barrier (ΔΔG ‡ = 1.5 kcal/mol) and supporting the observed enantioselectivity. The predictive accuracy of this model was validated by applying it to a more selective catalyst (system 2 in Fig. 9): as in the case of Takemoto’s catalyst, a difference in RDS and a clear reactivity preference between the enantiofaces were observed [33]. DFT calculations (B3LYP-D3(cPCM)/TZVP//B3LYP-D3/6–31G(d)) revealed an increased energetic difference between the two enantiomers (Fig. 11 , ΔΔG ‡ = 3.5 kcal/mol), confirming the enhanced stereoselectivity. This result aligns with experimental data: (R,R)-2 selectively consumes l -lactide, leading to a conversion close to 50 %, consistent with a kinetically controlled resolution. A recent study by Chen and co-workers reported a bifunctional thiourea-based organocatalyst, cis-(R,S)-dithiourea (DiTU) (Fig. 9, catalyst 3), which, in combination with potassium methoxide (MeOK) as co-catalyst, enabled the synthesis of highly isotactic PLA (Pₘ = 0.92) from rac-LA under mild conditions (25 °C, THF) [34]. This remarkable stereoselectivity was attributed to a mechanism of “oscillatory adaptive catalysis” (OAC), which relies on dual recognition of both the chain-end and the incoming monomer’s chirality through two switchable catalytic sites. These are formed upon selective deprotonation of the two thiourea (TU) moieties by MeOK, generating the mirror-symmetric active species CATA and CATA′ (Fig. 12 ). DFT calculations (M06–2X-D3(cPCM)/6–311++G(2d,2p)//M06–2X-D3/6–31G(d)) revealed that CATA preferentially incorporates d -LA, while CATA′ favours l -LA, with energetic differences of 6.4 and 4.8 kcal/mol, respectively, over the mismatched enantiomer. These findings indicated that both species are intrinsically stereoselective, supporting the operation of an ESC mechanism during polymerization. During propagation, the stereochemistry of the growing chain end determines which thiourea (TU) moiety becomes catalytically active. Following the ring-opening step, the resulting alkoxide is stabilized through deprotonation of one TU group leading to the formation of either CATA or CATA′, depending on the stereochemical match. For instance, the insertion of d -LA into CATA favours chain-end transfer to the thiourea unit linked to the S-stereocenter (matched case), while insertion of l -LA results in transfer to the R-centred TU, thereby converting CATA into CATA′ (mismatched case). This intramolecular chain shuttling dynamically switches the active site, enabling stereochemical autocorrection (Fig. 13 ). DFT calculations showed that propagation with a matched monomer–chain-end pair proceeds with a lower barrier, while mismatched insertions are disfavoured and trigger site switching. Overall, this pendulum-like mechanism allows the catalyst to adapt its stereochemical preference in real time, ensuring high isoselectivity and enabling the formation of stereo-block PLA when misinsertions occur. While most stereoselective ROP studies have focused on rac-LA, leading to advances in isotactic PLA synthesis, far fewer investigations have explored the stereoselective polymerization of meso‑LA using metal-free catalysts. Among these, achiral organocatalysts such as triazabicyclodecene (TBD) and N-heterocyclic carbenes (NHCs) have demonstrated the ability to produce heterotactic PLA from meso‑LA at low temperatures [25,39]. More recently, attention has turned to investigate the same thiourea-based systems previously discussed for the stereoselective ROP of rac-lactide—namely, Takemoto’s catalyst (Fig. 9, catalysts 1) but in the polymerization of meso‑lactide. Despite this system exhibits high isoselectivity in the polymerization of rac-LA, it affords the formation of a weakly syndiotactic PLA at room temperature (P m= 0.62). DFT [40] investigation (B3LYP-D3(cPCM)/TZVP//B3LYP-D3/6–31G(d)) performed on ROP of meso‑LA promoted by Takemoto’s catalyst, considered both monomer reactive sites, defined as meso‑A and meso‑B, depending on whether the reactive acyl oxygen is adjacent to an R- or S-methine centre. The influence of the monomer’s enantioface (re or si) and the chirality of the growing chain, determined by the configuration of the last inserted unit, was also considered. As shown in Fig. 14 , during initiation, the nucleophilic addition of BnOH (TS1) is the RDS for both meso‑A and meso‑B, each favouring attack at opposite monomer enantiofaces (re for meso‑A and si for meso‑B). The calculated energetic preference for meso‑A (re) over meso‑B (si) is 1.1 kcal/mol, indicating a reduced ESC compared to that observed in the polymerization of rac-LA (Fig. 9). Propagation was examined by modelling the addition of a second meso‑LA monomer to chains terminated with either meso‑A or meso‑B units. For meso‑A chain type, both reactive sites favoured addition via the si enantioface, with a modest preference of 0.8 kcal/mol for meso‑A. In contrast, for meso‑B-terminated chain, both monomer configurations preferred the re enantioface, with meso‑B being favoured by 1.0 kcal/mol. These findings were further supported by Activation Strain Model [36,37] analysis, which revealed that, despite the presence of strong catalyst–monomer interactions, the stability of transition state is primarily governed by strain energy, favouring pathways with minimal geometric distortion. Fig. 15 presents the DFT optimized structures of the enantio‑determining RDSs of meso‑LA on both meso‑A and meso‑B chain types, along with the corresponding NCI analysis [38]. NCI analysis revealed a larger green isosurface between the catalyst and the growing chain in the case of the meso‑B chain (Fig. 15),indicating the presence of weak, attractive noncovalent (CH-π and CH-F) interactions that contribute to transition state stabilization. These findings support the role of CEC in modulating reactivity during propagation. Overall, DFT calculations revealed that the ROP of meso‑LA promoted by Takemoto’s catalyst proceeds through multiple and energetically similar pathways (<1 kcal/mol), resulting in poor enantiodiscrimination and low stereoregularity of the resulting polymer (P m= 0.62). This outcome reflects an antagonistic interplay between ESM and CEM, in contrast to the synergistic mechanism observed in rac-LA polymerization, and accounts for the reduced stereocontrol. These findings illustrate how subtle changes in noncovalent interactions can dictate the balance between ESC and CEC, thereby significantly influencing polymer stereochemistry. Similar mechanistic principles also govern stereocontrol in the polymerization of related monomers, such as O-carboxyanhydrides, as reported in the next section. 2.2 ROP of mandelic O-carboxyanhydride Thio(urea)-based catalysts have also been explored in the ROP of other cyclic monomers. For example, Koca et al. investigated the stereochemical control in the ROP of mandelic O-carboxyanhydride (manOCA) using bifunctional, single-component organocatalysts derived from (thio)ureas (Fig. 16 ) [41] In these systems, optimal stereocontrol is achieved through a fine-tuned balance between the hydrogen-bond donating capacity of the (thio)urea moiety and the basicity of the pyridine-derived unit. This intramolecular synergy facilitates efficient monomer activation while minimizing epimerization at the monomer’s stereocenter [42,43]. 1TU-A catalyst emerged as the most effective catalyst, achieving high conversion and producing a highly isotactic polymer (P m = 0.90). In this system, the tert‑butyl group reduces the basicity of the pyridine unit, thereby suppressing undesired deprotonation of the α-hydrogen of the monomer. At the same time, the two CF3 substituents increase the acidity of the thiourea NH protons, strengthening the hydrogen bonding with the monomer’s carbonyl group (Fig. 17 A). As a result, the polarization of the carbonyl group is enhanced and facilitates a more selective nucleophilic attack by the initiator. This dual effect helps reduce the partial positive charge on the α-hydrogen at the stereocenter, thereby minimizing the risk of epimerization (Fig. 17B). DFT calculations (B3LYP-D3(cPCM)/6–31+G*//B3LYP-D3/6–31+G*) confirmed that the urea analogue catalyst (1U-A) exhibits the highest activation energy, highlighting the superior ROP catalytic activity of thioureas over ureas. In contrast, 1TU-B complex bearing a Cl atom in the ortho position of the pyridine ring, displayed a slightly lower activation barrier than 1TU-A, resulting in a faster polymerization rate. However, the increased basicity of its pyridine unit led to a polymer with reduced isotacticity. Overall, this study demonstrates that fine-tuning bifunctional organocatalysts, in this case by modulating hydrogen-bond donor strength and pyridine basicity, can be strategically leveraged to control the stereochemistry of the resulting polymer. 2.3 ROP of rac-diolide Another chiral cyclic monomer of growing interest is rac-diolide (DL), an eight-membered cyclic dimer derived from the renewable resource 3-hydroxybutyric acid. Structurally analogous to lactide and containing two stereocenters, rac-DL can give rise to polymers with distinct stereoregularities, such as isotactic, atactic, or heterotactic, depending on the selectivity of the catalyst. Tao et al. reported explored the use of chiral phosphoric acids (CPAs) as organocatalysts to promote the isoselective ROP of rac-DL (Fig. 18 ) [44]. These systems possess a markedly different structural framework compared to those discussed in the previous sections. Nevertheless, the similarity in their monomer activation mode and the bifunctional activation ability (as observed for TBD and ureas) enable a direct comparison of their stereocontrolling polymerization mechanism with that established for lactide. To this extent, CPAs facilitate the formation of a well-defined supramolecular complex among the catalyst, monomer, and initiator/chain-end through both hydrogen bond donor and acceptor groups, thereby enabling effective transfer of chiral information during polymerization. Various (R)-binaphthol scaffolds were evaluated to fine-tune selectivity by carefully balancing steric and electronic effects (Fig. 19 ). Among them, R-CPA5, featuring a phenyl ring substituted at the 1, 3, and 5 positions with isopropyl groups, exhibited the best performance, yielding poly(3-hydroxybutyrate) (P3HB) with moderate isotacticity, as indicated by an mm triad content of approximately 71 %. Experimental results support a multiblock copolymerization mechanism that produces gradient isotactic multiblock copolymers, with stereochemical control arising from a dual contribution of ESC and CEC mechanisms with CEC playing a dominant role for isospecific CPAs. To gain deeper insight into the origin of stereocontrol, DFT calculations (B3LYP-D3(SMD)/6–311+g(2d,p)//B3LYP-D3/6–31G(d,p)) were performed. For computational simplicity, the growing polymer chain was represented as a chiral alcohol bearing a single stereocenter, designated as either the S-chain or R-chain, depending on its configuration. All intermediates and transition states were calculated under the assumption of a dual activation mechanism, i.e. the phosphoric acid’s O–H and P = O groups simultaneously interact with the monomer and the growing chain, as suggested by the NMR analyses (Fig. 20 ). Comparison of activation barriers for the nucleophilic attack of the hydroxyl chain-end on the monomer carbonyl via TS1 revealed strong chiral discrimination. With R-CPA5 and a R-chain, insertion of the R,R-DL monomer was favored by 7.3 kcal/mol over S,S-DL, indicating a kinetic preference consistent with CEC. In contrast, for the S-chain, the preference for S,S-DL was minimal (0.4 kcal/mol), showing asymmetric discrimination. Thermodynamically, R-CPA5 favours S-configured chains, likely due to steric interactions with the R-chain’s methyl group, suggesting a contribution from ESC, whereby the catalyst selectively stabilizes one enantiomer. Early in the reaction, R-CPA5 preferentially reacts with (R,R)-DL, producing an R-configured chain that kinetically favors further (R,R) insertion, forming long isotactic –R–R–R– blocks. As (R,R) concentration drops, the incorporation of (S,S) monomer becomes more likely as this shift is thermodynamically favored: the intermediate 2INT1 (R-chain + S,S monomer) is about 2 kcal/mol more stable than 1INT1 (R-chain + R,R monomer). Despite the higher barrier for (S,S) insertion, stereoerrors lead to formation of S-configured chains, which in turn preferentially incorporate additional (S,S) monomers, forming –S–S–S– blocks. However, due to the small energy difference (0.4 kcal/mol), these S-blocks tend to be shorter. Overall, the ROP of rac-DL catalyzed by CPAs is governed by overlapping mechanisms: early kinetic control (CEC) drives insertion of R,R monomers, while thermodynamic control (ESC) takes over as the monomer composition evolves. This dynamic interplay produces gradient isotactic block copolymers and showcases a novel strategy for achieving precise stereochemical control via organocatalysis. 2.4 Polymerization of methacrylates In this final section, we move beyond ring-opening polymerizations to present a polymerization that proceeds through a completely different mechanism, illustrating how computational studies can aid in rationalizing tacticity control across diverse processes. A notable example is the 2022 study by Sun et al. who reported a self-controlled stereospecific polymerization of bulky methacrylates using N-heterocyclic olefin (NHO) organocatalysts in strong donating solvents such as dimethylformamide (DMF) (Fig. 21 ) [45]. This strategy enables the synthesis of highly isotactic polymers (with mm values up to 98.2 %) over a broad temperature range (25 to 90 °C), thereby overcoming the inherent syndiotactic tendency of methacrylates under mild conditions [46–48]. In this type of polymerization, the mechanism differs significantly: the NHO catalyst adds to the double bond of the methacrylate monomer, generating a propagating enolate anion (Scheme 5 ). This anion remains paired with the positively charged NHO⁺ species, forming a solvent-dependent ion pair that plays a pivotal role in controlling the stereochemical outcome of each monomer insertion. Thus, here the stereocontrol arises from two factors: the use of a nucleophilic NHO initiator, which limits side reactions, and the choice of a polar solvent, which promotes the formation of free/loose ion pairs. The results obtained challenges the conventional rules of ionic polymerizations, where tight ion pairs in weakly donating solvents (e.g. toluene) are considered essential for stereoregulation [49–50]. Here, DMF facilitates ion dissociation, unlocking a self-controlled mechanism governed purely by steric effects: with minimized electrostatic interactions, steric repulsion between the bulky groups of the propagating chain and the incoming monomer favours meso‑selective insertions. The solvent-dependent nature of the process was further elucidated through DFT calculations (M06–2X-D3(cPCM)/6–311++G//M06–2X-D3/6–31G(d,p)) modelling the propagation step in the gas phase, DMF, and toluene. In the gas phase, a strong kinetic preference for syndiotactic propagation was found. In contrast, DMF favoured isotactic insertion both kinetically and thermodynamically, due to the negligible hydrogen bonds between the NHO cation and the enolate anion. This allows free ion pairs to adopt conformations that maximize steric discrimination during monomer addition. In toluene, the energy barriers and stability of isotactic and syndiotactic pathways were found nearly equivalent, consistent with the lower isotacticity observed experimentally (mm = 59.2 %). DFT-optimized geometries of the propagating ion pair (Fig. 22 ) support these results: close cation–anion interactions dominate in the gas phase and in toluene, while DMF leads to dissociated species that favour sterically driven control. 3 Conclusions DFT has emerged as a powerful and versatile tool for unravelling the complex stereochemical mechanisms that govern organocatalyzed polymerizations. Applied across different monomer families—such as lactide, diolide, O-carboxyanhydrides, and methacrylates—computational studies have elucidated key non-covalent interactions, conformational dynamics, and activation modes that control stereoselectivity. These insights have clarified how catalyst structure, chain-end configuration, and reaction conditions work together to influence the stereochemical outcome of polymer growth. The organocatalytic systems reviewed reveal a rich diversity in both chemical structure and mechanistic pathways, yet common principles can be identified. Proline-derived catalysts, operating predominantly via an ESC mechanism, exemplify stereocontrol driven by the chiral environment of the catalyst, where noncovalent interactions between the catalyst, monomer, and initiator dictate monomer insertion. Similarly, thiourea-based catalysts combine ESC and CEC contributions, with stereocontrol arising from both chain-end interactions and catalyst–monomer recognition. In contrast, TBD imposes stereocontrol primarily through a CEC mechanism, where the configuration of the growing chain end dictates subsequent insertions. By comparison, the DMAP: MSA system achieves stereoregularity through supramolecular ion pairing, which suppresses epimerization rather than influencing propagation. Although catalyst scaffolds range from rigid, highly substituted proline derivatives to flexible bifunctional thioureas or phosphoric acids, successful stereocontrol in all cases depends on fine-tuned noncovalent interactions, dual activation of monomer and initiator, and the conformational constraints of the catalyst. DFT studies show that subtle changes in hydrogen-bonding networks or steric hindrance can shift the balance between ESC and CEC contributions, significantly affecting polymer tacticity. This interplay underscores why direct comparisons between catalysts with very different skeletons are not straightforward. Nonetheless, understanding these mechanistic features within each catalyst class provides valuable insights for rational design: the conformational preferences, activation modes, and interaction patterns identified via DFT can be leveraged to optimize existing catalysts or develop new ones with improved stereocontrol. Despite these promising results, DFT investigations in this area remain relatively limited. The field of stereoselective organopolymerization is still largely driven by experimental exploration, and computational approaches are often underutilized. With this perspective, we aim to highlight the untapped potential of DFT as a predictive and rational design tool. By enabling the detailed characterization of transition states, energy profiles, and supramolecular arrangements, DFT can complement experimental efforts and accelerate the development of next-generation organocatalysts with enhanced stereocontrol. As the field advances toward more sustainable and tunable polymerization strategies, integrating computational modelling into the catalyst design process will be essential. We hope this review encourages broader adoption of DFT methods to unlock new levels of control and mechanistic understanding in stereoselective organocatalysis. coredata.dc:description: Achieving precise control over stereochemistry in polymerization processes remains an essential goal of modern polymer science, as it directly impacts material properties such as crystallinity, degradability, and mechanical strength. Organocatalysis has emerged as a powerful strategy, offering metal-free conditions, structural tunability, and broad monomer compatibility. However, the origin of stereocontrol in these systems often hinges on subtle noncovalent interactions and conformational effects that are challenging to elucidate experimentally. In this perspective, we highlight how density functional theory (DFT) has provided critical insights into the mechanisms governing enantio‑ and diastereoselectivity in organocatalyzed polymerizations. We discuss representative case studies involving ring-opening polymerization (ROP) and conjugate-addition polymerizations, emphasizing how computational models have clarified the role of hydrogen bonding, steric hindrance, catalyst chirality, and monomer orientation in dictating tacticity. Furthermore, we examine how DFT complements experimental data in the rational design of new catalysts and explore the limitations and emerging frontiers in computational polymer catalysis. By bridging theory and practice, DFT-based studies are poised to accelerate the development of next-generation stereoselective organocatalysts.
